item.title: Mattress and furniture dumped in our bin cupboard!!, 4th July
item.description:
We now cannot access our bins due to furniture being dumped inside our bin unit in Blendon House on Wadding Street. This waste includes a disgusting mattress and it needs to be removed. As this item is a health and fire safety concern for this block of flats
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Stead Street, Walworth, London

item.title: Rubbish not collected causing fly infestation, 4th July
item.description:
Bins have not been collected and the fly infestation is getting incredibly bad and is now a health hazard to residents. There is no way to report this elsewhere on the council website and no one is answering calls.

Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Nevill Road, Hackney, London

item.title: Bollard knocked down outside 182 Rowley Avenue Sidcup, 4th July
item.description:
Bollard knocked down. Happened several times in a few months. Needs to be put back in other wise cars come up on the pavement and this is a danger to pedestrians. Knocked down outside 182 Rowley Avenue, Sidcup. I had reported a few months back and got report back saying it had been fixed but it hadn't. We have propped it up in the hole for now to prevent cars coming up on the curb/pavement but it is not secured in the concrete. Please can someone look at this as a matter of urgency and can they secure it. Whoever checked it before may not have checked it correctly. Whilst it's now standing up in the hole it's in no way secure or safe. The report's reference number is 7182713. Please quote this if you need to contact the council about this report.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 180, Rowley Avenue, Blendon, Sidcup, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Antisocial behaviour, 4th July
item.description:
Along the Surrey Canal Walk there are groups that gather under both bridges using drugs and is very intimidating to walk through in the morning and Iâ€™m sure at other times of the day. I have had to call the police due to this and have seen the police there on many occasions and it does feel unsafe.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Surrey Canal Walk, Old Kent Road, London

item.title: Graffiti (see photo), 4th July
item.description:
Directly OPPOSITE 56 Abbey Road London NW8 0QD is a white piece of street furniture on the pavement covered with large ugly purple graffiti as shown in attached photo. Please can this be removed. Many thanks.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 58, Abbey Road, St. John's Wood, London

item.title: The pavement is covered in bushes, 4th July
item.description:
This has been for about a year ,I use a mobility scooter and the pavement is unusable due to bushes that now are on the kerb side almost in the rd .on whalebone Lane north going towards hainault .I have 2 sons in the cemetery that I'd like to visit, you couldn't even push a pram or ride a bike at all ..I'm not sure whose responsibility the pavement is. I'd be ever so grateful if this can be rectified ASAP. Many thanks
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Complaint, 4th July
item.description:
Please see original complaint:494837 for reference prior to below. Further to my complaint dated 5th February 2025, I must express my deep disappointment regarding the way this matter has been handled. It is wholly unacceptable that it has taken over five months for Bromley Council to take action in response to an issue we raised immediately after the incident. My husband continues to suffer significant discomfort and mobility issues as a result of the serious shoulder injury he sustained due to the dangerous condition of the pavement on Eden Way. At the time, both my daughter and I contacted you to report this incident and make you aware of the severe impact it had on our family. Despite this, the matter was initially dismissed, seemingly on the grounds that multiple complaints had not been madeâ€”an incredibly frustrating and insensitive response given the circumstances. We experienced, firsthand, the distress and complications that followedâ€”emergency treatment, surgery, and prolonged recovery, all stemming from a hazard that could and should have been addressed promptly. It is only now, five months later, that the council has chosen to acknowledge the issue and accept responsibility. This delay is not only unacceptable but has also compounded the suffering endured by my husband and our family. I would appreciate a formal response outlining the steps Bromley Council intends to take both to resolve this matter and to ensure similar failures do not occur in future.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Eden Way, Eden Park, London
Report on FixMyStreet
